Award.AwardTitle: The Social Organization of Collaboration in the Chemical Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Science is an increasingly collaborative venture. To understand important issues in science policy, one must thus understand scientific collaboration. Two pressing, current issues in science policy involve women's participation in science and ethical issues in science. This project investigates collaboration in the chemical sciences in order to develop deeper knowledge about both women in science and how scientists think broadly about ethical issues and responsibilities in their field. The United States' continuing competitiveness in developing innovative science and engineering demands both broader participation in those fields and continuing high standards of research.

Despite over thirty years of research on women in science (mostly in purely academic settings) and significant investments, the persistence of gender gaps in science remains without an adequate explanation. Investigation of the chemical sciences allows this project to look at the determinants of success in research collaborations, both in academic and industrial settings. Although policies and programs for recruiting women to science make assumptions about why women are drawn to science (e.g., for altruistic reasons like helping others), very little research to date has investigated the social processes and organizational contexts by which gender can be related to broad ethical approaches to science. This project employs rigorous qualitative methods -- a combination of intensive interviews with women and men chemical scientists and ethnographic observation of their research collaboration meetings -- to build new, empirically-grounded theory. The observation methods in this project allow for investigation of (1) how different approaches to collaboration among men and women chemists are employed on a daily basis and (2) which kinds of laboratory organization are most conducive to innovative collaboration. Interviews with chemical scientists provide data on how scientists think about responsibilities of scientists in their field, including perceived responsibilities in research collaboration. The sustained three-year observation allows for following the arc of collaborative research relationships over time. Given that collaboration is a key mechanism in the process of knowledge production in chemical sciences, investigating what it looks like on the ground (i.e., what scientists view as worth pursuing and how they manage collaboration) is vital to understanding the productivity of science investments.

Broader impacts

The contributions of this project to the science of science policy and innovation are expected to include building basic social-science knowledge about collaboration, with a particular emphasis on the respective involvements of women and men in research collaboration and how scientists think about their collaborative responsibilities. This project provides new data and derived insights on how to address collaboration and career issues for women in science, which will be crucial for future decision-makers who seek a grounded basis for policies that create greater equity. The focus on integrating equity and ethical climates provides insights into how responsible conduct of research training improves both payoffs from investments and the scientific work environment. This project also integrates research and teaching; graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher working with the principal investigators will have opportunities to learn to be effective collaborators in the social sciences while they are studying the theory of effective collaboration and observing and analyzing the outcomes of research collaboration in the chemical sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project examines the role of collaboration in the chemical sciences. This investigation includes scientists’ understanding of their responsibilities in collaboration, and how women and men collaborate in the chemical sciences. The specific context of the research is the chemical sciences, an area of academic research long connected to research in industrial firms in the US. Qualitative observational and interview methods in four different academic and industrial settings provide data for building theory about how collaborative interactions--including interdisciplinary collaboration, a growing focus of scientific activity--may play out differently in different settings. The data include 106 interviews.

An important methodological contribution of this project is that qualitative data were collected from both academic and industry contexts, providing a unique opportunity for in-depth, cross-sector comparisons of collaboration. One study from this project (Smith-Doerr, Croissant, Vardi, and Sacco 2016) found that interdisciplinary collaboration was discussed in coherent ways across academic and industry labs, but was much more ambiguous in practice. Nearly all scientists expressed interest in interdisciplinary collaboration, but faced different constraints across the sites. In academia, tensions arose around practices linked to evaluation, such as publishing. In industry, time pressures and competition within the firm often strained how collaboration was practiced, creating tensions between work groups and inhibiting open collaboration.

A key finding of the project is that for chemical scientists, collaboration is inseparable from science; and yet while it is a core research practice, very little attention is given to training scientists how to collaborate, and little explicit guidance is available for how to set up scientific organizations to overcome challenges in collaboration. The result of this unreflective approach to collaboration is that it then becomes difficult to improve collaborative research, including highly productive collaboration that brings together scientists with diverse backgrounds by discipline, gender, race, and nationality.  The findings from this project provide knowledge that can inform a more intentional approach to collaboration. One study currently underway (Sacco, Smith-Doerr, and Croissant, in preparation) examines how collaborations succeed or fail in the eyes of the scientists. The vast majority of research on collaboration has been conducted using publication data; not only does this miss the dynamic processes inherent to collaborative relationships, it also misses the collaborations that do not produce a publication. This study finds publication is only one way collaborations come to be defined as successful, and it misses many collaborations that chemical scientists in industry experience. Through this study, a nuanced view of failed and successful collaboration that is more accurate to how scientists experience these working relationships is theorized.

The significant scientific advances and technological developments that have come from collaborative research, and interdisciplinary scientific collaboration in particular, have led to greater resources for collaborative projects. Although greater attention and funding has been given to collaborative research, less has been provided for understanding the social organization of collaboration. This project lays some of the theoretical and empirical groundwork for better understanding the social organization of collaboration in the chemical sciences. The publications from this project to date provide insights into: women and men scientists’ perceived responsibilities in collaboration (Smith-Doerr, Vardi, and Croissant 2016), the practices chemical scientists develop around ethics policies (Smith-Doerr and Vardi 2015), the gap between how interdisciplinary collaboration is talked about and what it looks like in action (Smith-Doerr, Croissant, Vardi, and Sacco 2016), the barriers to young women scientists’ confident presentation of results (Smith-Doerr, Sacco, and Stoutenburgh 2016), and the role of women scientists in leading knowledge production and entrepreneurship in industry settings (Vardi and Smith-Doerr 2014).
